boil.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: when a liquid boils, or when you boil it, it becomes hot enough to turn into gas
boil.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Put the spaghetti into plenty of boiling salted water.
We were advised to boil the water before drinking it.
boil.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to cook something in boiling water
boil.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She fried the chicken and put the vegetables on to boil.
boil.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: if something containing liquid boils, the liquid inside it is boiling
boil.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The kettle’s boiling – shall I turn it off?
The saucepan boiled dry on the stove.
boil.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to wash something, using boiling water
boil.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I always boil the cotton sheets.
boil.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if you are boiling with anger, you are extremely angry
boil.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Lewis was boiling with rage and misery.
boil.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Boil belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
boil.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: In this sentence, ‘the potatoes’ is the object of boil
boil.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: In this sentence, ‘the potatoes’ is the subject of boil
boil.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a painful infected swelling under someone’s skin
boil.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The boy’s body is covered in boils.
